{{short description|Heat and electrical energy from the sun in the Eurasian country}} [[File:SolarGIS-Solar-map-Turkey-en.png|thumb|upright=1.25|[[Insolation|Solar potential]]]] [[Turkey]] is located in an advantageous position in the [[Middle East]] and [[Southeast Europe]] for [[solar energy]]. Solar potential is very high in Turkey, especially in the South Eastern Anatolia and Mediterranean provinces.{{Cite journal | last1 = DAWOOD | first1 = KAMRAN| doi = 10.17694/bajece.06954| title = Hybrid wind-solar reliable solution for Turkey to meet electric demand| journal = Balkan Journal of Electrical and Computer Engineering| volume = 4 | issue = 2 | pages = 62–66 | year = 2016 | url = http://dergipark.gov.tr/bajece/issue/36581/415798}} Compared to the rest of the region{{clarify|reason=what region?|date=December 2019}}, insolation values are higher and conditions for solar power generation are comparable to [[Solar power in Spain|Spain]]. 7.5 TWh was generated in 2018 which was 2.5% of Turkey's electricity.{{cite web |title=Solar |url=https://www.enerji.gov.tr/en-US/Pages/Solar |publisher=[[Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources (Turkey)]] |accessdate=19 February 2019}} Installed capacity was 5GW, with the [[Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources (Turkey)|Energy Ministry]] planning to have another 10GW installed in the 2020s.{{cite web |title=Opportunities to strengthen the YEKA auction model for enhancing the regulatory framework of Turkey's power system transformation |url=https://www.shura.org.tr/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/SHURA_Opportunities-to-strengthen-the-YEKA-auction-model-for-enhancing-the-regulatory-framework-of-Turkeys-power-system.pdf |accessdate=19 February 2019}} However solar power in Turkey could increase far more quickly if subsidies for coal were abolishedOECD (2019), page 36 and the auction system was improved. == Insolation == * The annual average total [[insolation]] duration is 2741 hours (7.5 hours per day).{{Cite web|url=http://www.enerji.gov.tr/en-US/Pages/Solar|title=Republic of Turkey Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources - Solar|website=enerji.gov.tr|access-date=2020-03-23}} * Average annual solar radiation is 1527 [[kilowatt-hour|kW·h]]/(m²·yr) or 4.18 kW·h/(m²·d). Covering one half of one percent of the land area of Turkey with solar panels would be sufficient to generate all of the electricity used.{{cn|date=December 2019}} == Policies, laws and incentives == Turkey enacted its second [[Renewable Energy Law]], namely Law No. 6094 Concerning the use of Renewable Energy Resources for the Generation of Electrical Energy, in 2010.[http://www.gunessistemleri.com/k6094.php Renewable Energy Law] Turkish government is also encouraging expansion and the utilization of solar energy for electricity generation. To stimulate investment in renewables, various incentive schemes have been introduced For example, renewable energy plants with an installed capacity of 500 kW or less are exempt from licensing obligations Solar energy sources are covered by this law, which decrees that facilities which generate electricity from renewable energy sources will be granted a renewable energy resources certificate (RER Certificate) which will entitle such facilities to benefit from the incentives provided by the Law. EMRA is the competent authority to grant the RER Certificates. Permission is required from the [[Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry (Turkey)|Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry]] before building a [[Photovoltaic power station|solar park]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.dailysabah.com/energy/2019/10/13/hotels-in-antalya-turn-to-solar-power-to-reduce-electricity-costs|title=Hotels in Antalya turn to solar power to reduce electricity costs|website=DailySabah|access-date=2019-10-20}} Systems producing up to 50KW (e.g. residential systems) are more lightly regulated than larger ones.{{cite web |url=http://english.solarbaba.com/regulation-residential-solar-released |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-09-23 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925132711/http://english.solarbaba.com/regulation-residential-solar-released |archivedate=2015-09-25 }} Systems producing up to 1-[[megawatt]] (MW) of energy do not need a license, and plugged into the national grid are eligible for payments of US$0.133 per kilowatt-hour for 10 years.{{Cite web | url=http://www.solarnovus.com/policy-in-turkey-encourages-renewable-energy-generation_N7146.html |title = Policy in Turkey Encourages Renewable Energy Generation - Solar Novus Today}} Systems producing over 1-[[megawatt]] (MW) of energy must be licensed, but only if they feed into the grid. Such licences often become mired in the bureaucracy which is meant to ensure the grid can cope.http://www.apricum-group.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/pv-magazine-September-2014_Turkish-solar-market.pdf As of May 2015 600MW of these larger installation tenders have been approved. The one off fee per MW varies considerably depending on the result of each tender. In the coming years solar energy will be feasible without any feed-in-tariff mechanism,{{Cite web | url=http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/rea/news/article/2013/10/why-should-investors-choose-the-turkish-solar-market |title = Why Should Investors Choose the Turkish Solar Market?|date = 2013-10-24}} however {{as of|2019|lc=y}} smaller tenders and lower interest rates are the key to the expansion of solar power.{{cite news |title=Tax incentives for solar energy |url=https://www.dailysabah.com/op-ed/2019/02/08/tax-incentives-for-solar-energy |work=Daily Sabah |date=8 February 2019}} == Heating and hot water == The main solar energy utilizations in Turkey are the [[Solar thermal collector|flat-plate collectors]] in domestic hot water systems. Turkey is one of the leading countries in the world with a total installed capacity of 10 GWth as of 2011 (129 kWth /1,000 inhabitants){{cite web|url=http://www.iea-shc.org/Data/Sites/1/publications/Solar-Heat-Worldwide-2013.pdf|title=SOLAR HEAT WORLDWIDE 2011}} and 15,000 solar water heaters as of 2015.{{cite web |title=How Turkey Can Ensure a Successful Energy Transition |url=https://www.americanprogress.org/issues/security/reports/2018/07/10/453281/turkey-can-ensure-successful-energy-transition/ |publisher=Center for American Progress |accessdate=19 February 2019}}{{unreliable source?|date=February 2019}} The industry is well developed for hot water with high quality manufacturing and export capacity, but not so much for space heating, and is hampered by subsidies for coal heating.OECD (2019), page 36 == Photovoltaics == [[Photovoltaics]] (PV) growth is expected to be slow in 2019 due to financing challenges, but pick up again some time in the 2020s.{{cite news |title=Tender cancellation affirms view of near-term Turkey renewables slowdown – Fitch Solutions |url=https://balkangreenenergynews.com/tender-cancellation-affirms-view-of-near-term-turkey-renewables-slowdown-fitch-solutions/ |publisher=[[Fitch Ratings|Fitch]] |date=8 February 2019}} From May 2018 ‘unlicensed’ PV projects can have a generation capacity of up to 5 MW. From 2020 [[Solar cell|solar cells]] are manufactured in Turkey.{{Cite web|url=https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/turkey-to-start-local-solar-cell-production-on-june-15/1764779|title=Turkey to start local solar cell production on June 15|website=www.aa.com.tr|access-date=2020-03-23}} In 2016 PV produced 3755 [[Joule|TeraJoules]],{{cite web |url= http://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=nrg_107a&lang=en | title= Supply, transformation and consumption of renewable energies - annual data (choose Solar and TeraJoule) |work=[[EuroStat]] |access-date=2019-05-24 }} about 1TWh of Turkey's 300TWh annual generation. {{As of|2017}} auction prices are around US$0.07 per kWh.{{Cite web|url=https://www.shura.org.tr/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/raporweb_ENG.pdf|title=Energy pricing and non-market flows in Turkey's energy sector|last=|first=|date=|website=SHURA Energy Transition Center|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}

{{Clear}} ==Rooftop small-scale PV== From 2019 the EPDK allowed [[net metering]] for homeowners and businesses installing 3-10 kW of PV on rooftops, so they can sell up to half of the electricity they generate to their electricity company, and receive payments equal to the price they pay.{{Cite web|url=https://www.dailysabah.com/op-ed/2019/02/08/tax-incentives-for-solar-energy|title=Tax incentives for solar energy|website=DailySabah|access-date=2019-10-04}} {{As of|2019}}, the payback period was estimated at 11 years: removal of VAT and the fixed government approval fee and attaching borrowing for installation to the property's mortgage has been suggested to shorten this.{{Cite web|url=https://ieefa.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/New-Incentives-Brighten-Turkey-Rooftop-Solar-Sector_December-2019.pdf|title=New Incentives Brighten Turkey's Rooftop Solar
